A groundbreaking study published in JAMA Pediatrics found that pregnant women exposed to higher levels of fluoride had children with lower IQ scores. This is alarming, as it suggests that fluoride in drinking water could be harming the cognitive development of future generations.

Moreover, fluoride has been linked to various other health issues. It can accumulate in the body over time, leading to skeletal fluorosis – a painful condition that causes joint pain, bone loss, and calcification of ligaments. Fluoride has also been implicated in thyroid dysfunction, as it can interfere with the production of thyroid hormones, potentially leading to hypothyroidism.

The dental benefits of fluoride, on the other hand, are largely derived from topical application, not ingestion. Brushing with fluoridated toothpaste is sufficient for preventing cavities, and there is little evidence that ingesting fluoride through drinking water provides any additional dental benefits.

In light of these risks, it is crucial that we reevaluate the practice of fluoridating drinking water. The potential harms far outweigh the supposed benefits, and it is our responsibility to protect public health. By removing fluoride from drinking water, we can safeguard the cognitive development of our children and reduce the risk of various health problems associated with fluoride exposure.
